translation.en: [woman] Ladies and gentlemen, the Honorable Justice Ginsburg.
translation.ja: 皆さんギンズバーグ最高裁判事です

translation.en: "I hereby declare, on oath..."
[Ginsburg] "...I will support and defend the Constitution..."
"...against all enemies..."
"...foreign and domestic."
[Ginsburg] "That I will bear arms..."
"...on behalf of the United States..."
"...when required by law."
[Ginsburg] After the words,
"We the people of the United States,"
translation.ja: 私たちはアメリカ国民となり

translation.en: the Constitution sets out the aspiration
translation.ja: 憲法は より完全な―

translation.en: to form a more perfect union.
translation.ja: 国家同一体を目指します

translation.en: We abolished slavery, prohibited racial discrimination,
translation.ja: 私たちは奴隷制の廃止と

translation.en: and made men and women people of equal citizenship stature...
translation.ja: 人種差別を禁止し男女平等の市民権を確立しました

translation.en: making ever more vibrant our national motto...
translation.ja: その結果 国家のモットーが強化されたのです

translation.en: "Out of Many, One."
[woman] All right, everybody, uh, good morning.
[group] Good morning.
[woman] Nice to see you all.
My name is Samantha Rijkers, and I am originally from the Netherlands.
translation.ja: 私はサマンサオランダからの移民よ

translation.en: When I started this job, I just felt so excited
translation.ja: 移民仲間である皆さんの―

translation.en: that I could help fellow immigrants also become citizens.
translation.ja: 市民権獲得を手伝えてうれしいわ

translation.en: [Rijkers] Since we are going to be spending a lot of time together,
translation.ja: しばらく一緒に活動をするので

translation.en: I always think it's nice for all of us to get to know each other a little bit.
translation.ja: 自己紹介から始めましょう

translation.en: All right.
-Who's ready to go first? -[group chuckles]
[woman] My name is Dipna,
I'm from Mexico,
-like my blouse. -[Dipna and group laugh]
translation.ja: ディプナ･コルドバこの服もね ディプナ･コルドバ

translation.en: I came here since 1989, so do the math.
translation.ja: 1989年の移民だから歳はそれなり

translation.en: I want to apply for a citizenship
because we came for better opportunities, for freedom.
translation.ja: 自由になる機会を得るため移住したけど

translation.en: Things are changing, something can happen with only the residence.
translation.ja: 状況は変わり今のままでは不安が大きい

translation.en: We have to become a citizens,
translation.ja: だから市民になりたいの

translation.en: that's why.
I came here to United States in 2012.
translation.ja: ２０１２年に米国に来たわ ２０１２年に米国に来たわファニー･ベロ ファニー･ベロ

translation.en: I was granted political asylum
because I was suffering persecution from the Venezuelan government.
translation.ja: ベネズエラ政府に迫害されてたの

translation.en: And I would like to become citizen.
For two reasons.
First of all,
because I think, uh...
this is the way to say thank you...
to this wonderful country.
And second,
because I love democracy and liberty.
translation.ja: 民主主義と自由への愛から

translation.en: [woman] I'm from Colombia.
I've been here about 21 years.
I come because I fell in love with him, my husband.
translation.ja: 理由は恋に落ちたから 理由は恋に落ちたからアレクサンドラ･Ａ 理由は恋に落ちたから

translation.en: And, you know, it's time to be a citizen,
translation.ja: この国が大好きよ この国が大好きよダゴベルト･Ａ

translation.en: because we love this country and we are scared about the future.
translation.ja: でも市民権がないと不安

translation.en: We want to be a part of the citizen,
translation.ja: アメリカ国民になりたいの

translation.en: so the next time we can vote.
We can have the rights. We can have the voice. We can count.
translation.ja: 確実な権利と発言権が欲しい

translation.en: [man] I want to become US citizen because I much appreciate freedom.
translation.ja: 市民権を目指す理由は自由を尊重するからだ

translation.en: There is no freedom in China,
translation.ja: 中国には自由がない 中国には自由がないジャン・チャン

translation.en: and people are also suffering there.
translation.ja: ジャン・チャン国民は苦しんでいる 国民は苦しんでいる

translation.en: If you say something, you will suffer some persecutions.
Here, we can spread the freedom to-- to-- to other place.
translation.ja: ここでは自由を広められる

translation.en: That's why I want to become American citizen here.
translation.ja: それが市民になりたい理由だ

translation.en: -Yeah, that's why. -[Rijkers] Thank you.
translation.ja: それが市民になりたい理由だ ありがとう

translation.en: [Rijkers] Follow me. We're going to our first painting.
What did you notice?
If you want to pass the citizenship test,
immigrants have to study 100 questions about American history and government, and they will be asked up to ten of those.
translation.ja: 米国の歴史や政治の質問に正解する必要がある

translation.en: They have to answer six correctly to pass.
Native Americans,
soldiers...
There's soldiers also in the back.
Those questions are about history, civics. They have to understand how the US government works.
translation.ja: 歴史や市民と政治との関りを理解する必要がある

translation.en: And for people who did not grow up in this country,
translation.ja: この国で育ってない移民には この国で育ってない移民にはサマンサ･ライカーズ ニューヨーク歴史協会

translation.en: who did not go to school in this country,
translation.ja: サマンサ･ライカーズ ニューヨーク歴史協会学校で習っておらず難しい質問よ

translation.en: that is very challenging.
translation.ja: サマンサ･ライカーズ ニューヨーク歴史協会学校で習っておらず難しい質問よ 学校で習っておらず難しい質問よ

translation.en: Who are the different people in this painting? And the other group...
How can we study history using paintings and artifacts?
translation.ja: 絵と展示物から歴史が分かる？

translation.en: What do you see in this painting?
[woman] It's winter.
-[Rijkers] How do you know it's winter? -[woman] It's snowy.
translation.ja: なぜ冬だと？ 雪がある

translation.en: [woman 2] And there's guns.
[Rijkers] Guns. What else?
-[woman] Families, children, babies. -Yeah.
[woman 2] They're guiding them to somewhere.
-[Rijkers] They're going somewhere. -[woman] Church.
How do you know they're going to church?
-Well, because of the pastors. -[woman] The priest.
[Rijkers] What is the family carrying?
-[woman] Books. -[Rijkers] Books.
-Probably Bibles. -[group] Bibles.
translation.ja: たぶん聖書 そうだ

translation.en: -[woman] Yes. -[woman 2] They're looking for something.
Yeah. What-- What could they be looking for?
[woman] Like, for a place?
Mm-hmm. Somewhere to go?
[woman] Maybe they're taking them to a place of safety.
Maybe it's unsafe. What could be the danger?
translation.ja: 危険なのよ どんな危険？

translation.en: Maybe they're coming back from...
participating in some sort of religious...
-[woman] Event. -...event, yeah.
[Rijkers] So,
it is dangerous for them to go.
So if they're going to church
and it is dangerous,
what does that tell us about these people?
[woman] They're not able to freely demonstrate their religion.
translation.ja: 宗教を隠しているように見える

translation.en: This painting is called Pilgrims Going to Church.
translation.ja: これは巡礼者が教会に行く絵よ

translation.en: And they came here for freedom.
translation.ja: 自由を求めて移民したの

translation.en: But specifically, freedom of religion. All right?
And that's what we can see here.
[woman] What kind of question do they ask, you know, in the 100 questions that will be related to this painting?
translation.ja: テストの質問はこの絵に関係あるの？

translation.en: [Rijkers] What is one reason colonists came to America?
-Religion. -[woman] Freedom, religion...
[Rijkers] Okay.
Already know one of the 100 questions. Right? We're good to go.
translation.ja: これで100の質問のうち１つは答えられる

translation.en: [woman] This is a time of great insecurity for many immigrants in our nation.
translation.ja: 多くの移民が不安を抱えている 多くの移民が不安を抱えているシチズンシップ・ナウ！法律講座 多くの移民が不安を抱えている

translation.en: Even for lawful permanent residents like many of you.
translation.ja: あなた方のように合法的でもジェニファー･シャンツニューヨーク歴史協会 ジェニファー･シャンツニューヨーク歴史協会

translation.en: [woman] Can you tell me how is it that you got your green card?
translation.ja: グリーンカード取得はどこで？

translation.en: Did they do that in the office,
or did you have to go to the court?
Court, ma'am, in the court.
One of the things that's great about becoming a US citizen
is that it gives you a certain amount of freedom.
translation.ja: 一定の自由を得られる 一定の自由を得られるアラン･ワーニック ニューヨーク市立大学

translation.en: Once you become a citizen, they can't take it away from you.
translation.ja: アラン･ワーニック ニューヨーク市立大学市民権は簡単に奪われない 市民権は簡単に奪われない

translation.en: [Dipna, in Spanish] Having citizenship is important
because of all the insecurity we're going through at the moment.
[in English] Can you read, write, and speak basic English?
translation.ja: 基本的な英語の読み書きは？

translation.en: -Yeah, I can write, I can read. -Very good.
[in Spanish] An immigrant is someone who comes to contribute to the country.
translation.ja: 〈その国に奉仕しようと移民する〉

translation.en: [woman, in English] Have you ever been ordered, removed,
translation.ja: アメリカ政府に― 入国を拒否されたり送還されたことは？

translation.en: excluded or deported from the United States?
translation.ja: 入国を拒否されたり送還されたことは？

translation.en: [Alexandra, in Spanish] The immigration situation is getting harder.
translation.ja: 〈移民の状況は厳しくなった〉

translation.en: And the stuff we are being told is starting to scare us.
[in English] Have you ever had any kind of military or weapons training?
[Dipna, in Spanish] When I was able to file the papers for my residency, my children were very happy,
translation.ja: 〈申請書が受理された時子供たちが喜んだわ〉

translation.en: because it assured us that we would be able to stick together.
[in English] Are you willing to bear arms on behalf of the United States?
translation.ja: 米国のため戦いますか？

translation.en: Yes.
[in Spanish] All immigrants are in pursuit of happiness.
translation.ja: 〈どの移民も幸せになりたい〉

translation.en: [woman, in English] If law requires it, are you willing to perform...
[Zhang, in Chinese] I think my greatest happiness is that I could come to America
translation.ja: 〈アメリカに来れたのが一番の幸せです〉

translation.en: and become an American citizen.
[Rijkers, in English] Look at the painting.
What did you notice?
[woman] People getting hurt...
[woman 2] Yeah, they tried to, like, take down the horse...
translation.ja: 馬を下ろそうとしてる

translation.en: [Rijkers] It's a horse. What else can you tell about the statue?
[man] The king. Right?
-How do you know it's a king? -[man] The crown.
[Rijkers] The crown, right?
Yeah, it's King George III of England.
So, on July 9th of 1776,
the Declaration of Independence reached New York City.
translation.ja: ニューヨークに独立宣言が届いた

translation.en: It took five days for news to travel from Philadelphia, where it was written, to New York.
translation.ja: フィラデルフィアから５日もかかったの

translation.en: They got so excited, a small group of George Washington's soldiers
translation.ja: 興奮したワシントン軍の兵士が

translation.en: ran down to the statue of King George III.
When they got to the statue, they started pulling it down.
translation.ja: 下ろそうと引っ張った

translation.en: If you look up, you can see
that's the real statue's horse's tail that survived.
translation.ja: 残された実物のしっぽがある

translation.en: -[group] Oh! -[Rijkers] It's right up there.
So, let's bring it back to the test.
When was the Declaration of Independence adopted?
translation.ja: 独立宣言はいつ認められた？

translation.en: -July. -[woman] July 4th.
It's July 4th, but it took until July 9th
for people in New York City to find out about it.
translation.ja: ニューヨーク市民がそれを知った

translation.en: So the answer is July 4th, 1776.
This is what it would have sounded like if you were at the Common on July 9th, 1776.
translation.ja: 1776年７月９日にこのような文が読まれたの

translation.en: "We hold these truths to be self-evident,
translation.ja: 独立宣言 “次のことは自明の真理だ”

translation.en: that all men are created equal,
translation.ja: 独立宣言 “全ての人間は平等だ” “全ての人間は平等だ”

translation.en: that they are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights,
translation.ja: “生存 自由そして幸福の追求を含む―”

translation.en: that among these are Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness."
translation.ja: “侵すべからざる権利を与えられている”

translation.en: [Zhang, in Chinese] Human beings are not willing to live in a locked-up space.
translation.ja: 〈人間は檻(おり)に閉じ込められたくない〉

translation.en: They aspire to live in a free terrain.
They aspire to have, for example, the right to religion,
the right to expression, the right to freedom.
translation.ja: 〈表現の自由自由である自由〉

translation.en: And the right to live in an unrestrained environment.
translation.ja: 〈拘束のない環境で生きる権利〉

translation.en: A poem goes like this,
“Life is dear, love is dearer.
Both can be given up for freedom.”
translation.ja: 〈“自由のためなら両方諦める”〉

translation.en: Freedom is a person’s highest pursuit.
translation.ja: 〈“自由のためなら両方諦める”〉 〈自由は何よりも貴重だ〉

translation.en: [Dagoberto, in Spanish] I had a tourist visa. At that time, they didn’t bother me.
translation.ja: 〈旅行ビザで入ったが気にしなかった〉

translation.en: I’d come, stay with my sister for a while.
At the time, getting a visa was a possibility, so I’d come over.
translation.ja: 〈当時はビザも取れそうだった〉

translation.en: In 2001, after the Twin Towers incident, that all stopped.
translation.ja: 〈9・11事件以降状況は変わった〉

translation.en: They became stricter with immigration laws.
translation.ja: 〈入国審査が厳しくなったので〉

translation.en: So I thought, "I’m not going back anymore."
[Alexandra] I didn’t know how hard it was to emigrate.
translation.ja: 〈移住の大変さを分かってなかった〉

translation.en: Because it’s not just about moving. It’s a different language and culture,
translation.ja: 〈移住だけじゃなく言葉や文化など〉

translation.en: lots of things to learn.
We went to the lawyer’s office.
That case cost us some 30,000 dollars,
because they announced in the news that the immigration fees were going up.
translation.ja: 〈移民ビザ申請料の値上げが発表されたから―〉

translation.en: They took advantage of us.
And to make matters worse,
its founder went to prison and everything went backwards.
translation.ja: 〈弁護士事務所の設立者が逮捕されたこと〉

translation.en: So we had to start all over and pay fees to yet another attorney to be represented,
translation.ja: 〈一からやり直しよ新しい弁護士を雇い―〉

translation.en: new fees to file the paperwork. It was a slow and difficult process to get our papers.
translation.ja: 〈書類を作り直したけど遅いし上手く行かなかった〉

translation.en: You come here, you get settled,
you learn to love this country, you get used to it,
you put down roots here, have a son.
[Dagoberto] It’s been many years. We’ve been here for 30 years.
[Alexandra] It’s been a whole life. Half of our lives here.
To become a citizen, you need...
to love this country, and we do.
We’re Colombians, but we feel like we’re from here. Half of our life is here.
translation.ja: 〈コロンビアでなく人生の半分を生きた米国に〉

translation.en: We’ve contributed
and we’ve done things how they should be done.
-[woman, in English] Good morning. -[Rijkers] Good morning!
Hello!
[in Spanish] Did you study at home? [in English] No practicing?
Uh-uh. Nothing.
[Rijkers, in English] We're gonna play a game.
So I want you to think, kind of talk through a timeline.
translation.ja: タイムラインを話し合って

translation.en: How is the United States changing, looking at this map?
translation.ja: 米国がどう変わっていったか 地図を見てね

translation.en: So, what area becomes part of the United States first,
translation.ja: この地域が最初の米国だけど

translation.en: and then what next?
I'll give you a few minutes to talk about this in your groups.
translation.ja: グループで考えてみて

translation.en: [woman] So, originally, this was the first states.
And that was part of the United States, but not yet states.
translation.ja: ここはまだ州じゃない

translation.en: What about Texas, it was, um, independent?
[Rijkers] It used to be part of Mexico, and then it was independent, -exactly. Yeah. -Okay.
translation.ja: 最初はメキシコでのちに独立した

translation.en: [in Spanish] Mexico was this big, and now it's like this.
translation.ja: 〈メキシコは大国だったわね〉

translation.en: All of California was Mexico.
All of this was Mexico.
translation.ja: 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年〈ここ全部ね〉

translation.en: -[Fanny] Why did you let them take it? -[woman] It was a Mexican president.
translation.ja: 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年〈なぜ米国に？〉 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年〈大統領が〉 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年

translation.en: -[Fanny] He sold it or what? -Yes.
translation.ja: 地域別買収１７７６年〜１８６６年〈売った？〉 〈そう〉

translation.en: How much did he take from that sale?
[woman, in English] Louisiana is so big.
The original are just these ones, 13.
The original, it is too small, right?
-[woman] Yes, it's small. -[Rijkers] Where's New York?
translation.ja: そうね ニューヨークはどこ？

translation.en: I also can't reach. It's over there.
translation.ja: 手が届かないわね　そこよ

translation.en: Where's the Mississippi River?
The different areas became part of the United States at different times.
translation.ja: 違う時期に違う地域が米国となった

translation.en: Louisiana Purchase, that doubled the size of the United States.
translation.ja: ルイジアナの買収は領土を２倍にした

translation.en: But eventually, Native Americans were forcibly removed from their lands.
translation.ja: 同時に原住民が土地を追われた

translation.en: After Florida, what became part of the United States next?
translation.ja: フロリダの次に領土になったのは？

translation.en: -[woman] Texas. -[Rijkers] Texas. Yeah.
What becomes part of the United States next?
-[man] Oregon. -[Rijkers] Oregon Country.
Yeah, now it's now Califor-- The state of California, part of it.
translation.ja: カリフォルニアの一部ね

translation.en: [Fanny, in Spanish] I was always very impressed
with the tenacity of those first immigrants.
translation.ja: 〈最初の移民の頑張りには〉 〈すごく感銘を受けたわ〉

translation.en: How they had to struggle to establish themselves here.
translation.ja: 〈生活を確立させるため苦労した〉

translation.en: I am Venezuelan in origin.
I began to work as a typist. I went from secretary
translation.ja: 〈タイピストとして働き始め次に秘書〉

translation.en: to section manager, to department manager, to division manager,
translation.ja: 〈そしてマネージャーとして次々と昇格し―〉

translation.en: to line manager, to general section director,
until I reached the position of bank president
translation.ja: 〈最後は銀行の頭取まで上り詰めて〉

translation.en: and, subsequently, Minister of Agriculture.
translation.ja: 〈その後 農業相になった〉

translation.en: Everything changed when a tyrant
ruined the economy of the country.
Venezuelans had never been immigrants, never.
Venezuelans would go on vacations, and we would return to Venezuela,
translation.ja: 〈休暇で出国しても皆 帰国したわ〉

translation.en: selling our leftover US dollars.
Now, there are more than four million Venezuelans outside of their country.
translation.ja: 〈今は400万人もの国民が国外に脱出する〉

translation.en: Families destroyed, families separated.
translation.ja: 〈家族は離ればなれで崩壊よ〉

translation.en: That is Venezuela. So I decided to write a book
translation.ja: 〈それがベネズエラよだから本を書く決意をした〉

translation.en: about the political, social, economic, and moral situation in Venezuela.
translation.ja: 〈国の政治 経済 道徳観念社会を題材にね〉

translation.en: We won’t be puppets managed by President Hugo Chávez.
translation.ja: 〈チャベス大統領の操り人形にはならない〉

translation.en: [voice-over] That was the tipping point, because the police came after me.
translation.ja: 〈それからが最悪だった警察に追われたの〉

translation.en: And it was a truly terrible moment,
because I knew they were criminals, and if I said or did anything,
translation.ja: 〈私が何かを言ったり行動したりすれば―〉

translation.en: it could have deadly consequences for me.
[Dipna] I entered on a tourist visa. I could come and go.
translation.ja: 〈昔は観光ビザで入出国が自由だった〉

translation.en: But after 9/11, they changed the visa system,
and that visa no longer functioned.
So I no longer had the possibility of changing that visa because I no longer had anything in Mexico.
translation.ja: 〈メキシコにつてもなくビザも変更できない〉

translation.en: So that’s when I decided to no longer leave this country.
Yes.
Okay, what’s the address?
Until finally, my son, when he turned 21,
he petitioned... for my residency.
translation.ja: 〈私の永住権を嘆願してくれたの〉

translation.en: Sometimes I have felt frustrated by some people’s attitudes.
Recently, someone told us to stop speaking Spanish.
translation.ja: 〈この間はバスで―〉 〈スペイン語じゃなく英語で話せと言われた〉

translation.en: They said we shouldn’t speak Spanish on the bus, that we should speak English.
translation.ja: 〈スペイン語じゃなく英語で話せと言われた〉

translation.en: It’s a very difficult experience.
You have to be really strong.
You learn how to leave your loneliness aside
and push yourself to try to get ahead for my sons.
translation.ja: 〈息子のため先に進まないと〉

translation.en: [Rijkers, in English] What do you see here?
-[woman] Slave auction. -[woman 2] One woman...
translation.ja: 奴隷売買 女性が１人

translation.en: Donna, you said right away slave auction. How do we know that is what's happening?
translation.ja: 真っ先に奴隷売買だとなぜ分かった？

translation.en: -Public auction. -It says "sales."
-"Great sale." -[Rijkers] "Great Sale."
"Great sale of horses, cattle, Negroes and other farm stock
translation.ja: “馬 家畜 黒人農園必需品”

translation.en: this day at public auction."
[Rijkers] What else? What is he wearing?
-[woman] Just casual kind of clothes. -[woman 2] Mm-hmm.
-What kind of shoes is he wearing? -[group] No shoes.
[Rijkers] But the woman also doesn't wear shoes.
What about the woman? Have we come to a consensus?
Have we agreed on what her role is in all this?
[Fanny] She looks worried, because probably she's thinking
translation.ja: 心配そうだわ　多分…

translation.en: that the boys are going to be taken from her.
translation.ja: 子どもを取られると思ってる

translation.en: [Rijkers] Yeah, that was a very, um... -Worry. -...real possibility for many families, that they would be taken apart.
translation.ja: 現実に 多くの家族が離ればなれにされたわ

translation.en: That some family members would be sold to one person
and others to another, and they would be separated. Mm-hmm.
translation.ja: １人が別の所だともう会えない

translation.en: [in Spanish] The slaves they brought over were essential in building the foundation of this country.
translation.ja: 〈奴隷売買がこの国の基礎を作った〉

translation.en: Sometimes, I think of everything they’ve gone through. Lots of suffering.
translation.ja: 〈彼らの大変な苦悩を想像するわ〉

translation.en: [Fanny] This is a multicolored country.
They came as slaves, but that contributed
to the melting pot that this beautiful country is.
translation.ja: 〈この国を形作った立派な一員よ〉

translation.en: [in English] So through art, John Rodgers showed...
translation.ja: 美術を通しジョン･ロジャースは―

translation.en: Well, he was political through his art, showing how horrible slavery was.
translation.ja: 奴隷制度の残酷さなど政治的メッセージを伝えた

translation.en: That families were being torn apart
and that people were being treated like animals. Right?
translation.ja: 動物のように扱われたわ

translation.en: They literally say they are like other animals.
translation.ja: ここに動物と同様に書かれている

translation.en: A major issue that led to the Civil War was slavery, as we can see here.
translation.ja: 奴隷制度は南北戦争の一因でもある

translation.en: Name one problem that led to the Civil War.
translation.ja: 南北戦争の原因の１つは？

translation.en: [group] Slavery.
Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived?
translation.ja: 移民が入る前誰が住んでいた？

translation.en: [group] Native Americans.
[Rijkers] What did the Emancipation Proclamation do?
translation.ja: 奴隷解放宣言の役割は？

translation.en: [group] Free the slaves.
So, thank you all for coming. See you next week.
translation.ja: では来週また会いましょう

translation.en: -Have a great week. -[woman] You too.
-[woman 2] Thank you. -[Rijkers] Mm-hmm.
[Fanny, in Spanish] This is the First Lady of the Republic,
translation.ja: 〈これは共和国大統領夫人よ〉

translation.en: this is the wife of the President of Congress, and this is me.
This is a small part of the materials I presented when I applied for asylum.
translation.ja: 〈これは亡命申請した時の資料の一部よ〉

translation.en: And this is the book that almost got me hanged.
translation.ja: 〈そして絞殺刑になりかけた著作〉

translation.en: [man] Fanny Bello writes a book.
It is a letter to President Chávez.
It's called Letter to a Falling Chávez.
translation.ja: 〈題は「墜(お)ちたチャベスへの手紙」〉

translation.en: [Fanny] I was permanently fighting against the government of Chávez.
translation.ja: 〈ずっとチャベス政権と戦いました〉

translation.en: What’s the message you want to send to the president, if he reads your book?
I hope he reconsiders.
Specifically, in one chapter, I tell him
that he should pray the "Confiteor" with conviction.
translation.ja: 〈自分が罪人であると認めて欲しい〉

translation.en: If we don’t react to this mess,
translation.ja: 〈この非常事態を放置すると〉

translation.en: we will end up being a franchise, and the owner will be Hugo Chávez.
translation.ja: 〈国民はチャベスの言いなりです〉

translation.en: [voice-over] They arrived in the morning
with guns in their hands, and soon the gun was at my head.
They broke my computer,
threw me to the ground, tied me up, and killed my dog.
translation.ja: 〈私を投げ倒して縛り犬を殺した〉

translation.en: They said they were doing this to stop me from publishing propaganda.
translation.ja: 〈プロパガンダである本の出版阻止のためだと〉

translation.en: And after that, well, I had to leave the country.
translation.ja: 〈その後私は亡命することに〉

translation.en: I was afraid that they were going to put me in prison, because the book hit them hard.
translation.ja: 〈監獄に入れられることを恐れたからよ〉

translation.en: I came through the Colombian border,
I flew to Bogota, and from there to here.
Chávez ruined the economy of the country.
In Venezuela, people are actually dying of hunger.
translation.ja: 〈国民は飢餓で死亡している〉

translation.en: [man] Who are we?
[all] Venezuela!
[Fanny] Long live Venezuela!
I am fighting now, and I will fight when I become a citizen.
Fighting to set Venezuela free from the present tyranny.
translation.ja: 〈ベネズエラを独裁から救うわ〉

translation.en: -[man, in English] Who are we? -[all] Venezuela!
translation.ja: 我々は？ ベネズエラ人

translation.en: -[man] What do we want? -[all] Freedom!
[Rijkers] I want to look at another image, so if you take one and pass.
translation.ja: まずこの絵を回して見てほしいの

translation.en: And some here...
Yeah, if you help those to the back as well.
-They're doing a Chinese wall. -[Rijkers] Yeah.
[woman] Look at all their faces.
[Rijkers] So, I heard a lot of great reactions to this.
Yeah. All right, so, again, so...
What are the people doing in this-- in this image?
-[woman] Building a wall. -[Rijkers] Building a wall?
translation.ja: 壁を作ってる 壁は？

translation.en: [woman] Anti-Chinese wall.
What does that mean, if they're building an anti-Chinese wall?
translation.ja: 反中国の壁は何を意味する？

translation.en: -[woman] They don't like the Chinese. -Mm-hmm.
They don't want them to come in. Who are the people building this wall?
[woman] The other immigrants.
[Rijkers] Other immigrants!
-Immigrants. -Other immigrants.
That's the same as today.
[Rijkers] How is it similar today?
They're gonna build, like, a-- a wall.
Mexico. From Mexico.
And they talk about all those things from the people.
-The same thing. -[Rijkers] Mm-hmm.
[Dipna] They want the best of the, uh, each country,
translation.ja: それぞれの国が最善を目指す

translation.en: but they don't want the people, just the products from it.
translation.ja: でも欲しいのは人じゃなく物

translation.en: They just want the product, yeah.
They benefit.
They benefit from them.
-History repeats. -[group] Yeah.
translation.ja: 歴史は繰り返す その通り

translation.en: [Dagoberto, in Spanish] When you talk about asbestos, people panic.
There always has to be someone who does the work that they don’t want to do.
translation.ja: 〈だけど誰かがやらなくちゃいけない〉

translation.en: That was one of the eligible jobs to get the papers.
translation.ja: 〈そんな仕事をすれば申請できる〉

translation.en: My boss told me, "Okay, we have to go and clean the Twin Towers."
translation.ja: 〈ツインタワーを片づけるとボスに言われた〉

translation.en: I hadn't really grasped what had happened.
translation.ja: 〈何が起こったのか知らなかった〉

translation.en: The scope of what had happened.
When I got there, wow.
[Alexandra] He worked there for one year.
I worked for about three months there.
We don’t know what can happen to us in the future.
[Dagoberto] I got asthma after that.
I wasn’t asthmatic before, and now I have it.
[Alexandra] We didn’t know how bad this was.
We couldn’t imagine what was in the air.
We were caught up...
in having work
and being useful.
In a few years, we can end up sick from that.
We can die, and isn’t that dying for this country?
translation.ja: 〈それで死ねば国のためじゃない？〉

translation.en: To help with that tragedy?
We think that we’ve earned the right to become citizens.
-Right? -[Dagoberto] Yes.
[woman, in English] Say "unemployed" and fill out your address.
translation.ja: 無職と書いて住所を入れて 無職と書いて住所を入れてシチズンシップ・ナウ！法律講座

translation.en: Have you ever been involved with any of the following:
translation.ja: シチズンシップ・ナウ！法律講座以下の活動の経験は？

translation.en: genocide,
translation.ja: シチズンシップ・ナウ！法律講座虐殺 虐殺

translation.en: torture, killing,
badly hurting a person on purpose...
Have you ever been arrested, charged with a crime,
-handcuffed by a police officer? -[man] No. No.
No. Got it, all right.
[woman] Were you ever a member of, or did you ever serve in or help, or participate in-- in any way in any kind of military group?
translation.ja: 過去に何らかの軍事活動に参加したことは？

translation.en: We'll see if you need any of that.
If you traveled a lot or had a lot of jobs,
-so we'll check on that. -[man] Can I have those papers?
Thanks.
[Alexandra, in Spanish] We are very afraid that the person who is leading us now
could lead us to something terrible.
Despite what’s happening now,
I think there are many good people who want change.
They say that it's always darkest before the dawn.
translation.ja: 〈“明けない夜はない”って言うでしょ〉

translation.en: [Rijkers] It's really powerful to see why people are coming to this country
translation.ja: 人々がこの国に移住し― 市民になりたい理由はとても切実よ

translation.en: and why they want to be a part of this country.
translation.ja: 市民になりたい理由はとても切実よ

translation.en: I think the United States government decided to include questions
translation.ja: 政府はテストの質問に

translation.en: about slavery, about the Civil War, because that is American history,
translation.ja: 奴隷制や公民権運動を加え歴史を学ばせる

translation.en: and if you don't understand the past
translation.ja: 過去を理解しなければ

translation.en: and you want to become a part of this country, you don't understand the present.
translation.ja: この国に属しても現在を理解できない

translation.en: [Rijkers] Um, so...
what did Martin Luther King Jr. do?
translation.ja: キング牧師は何をした？

translation.en: -[group] Fight for Civil Rights. -[Rijkers] Fought for Civil Rights.
We can also say that he worked for equality for all American people.
translation.ja: 国民の平等のため運動したとも言える

translation.en: Yeah.
I'm going to show you a video of a part of a speech that he gave.
translation.ja: 彼の演説のビデオを見せるわね

translation.en: How long will it take?
Somebody’s asking,
"How long will prejudice blind the visions of men?"
translation.ja: 偏見はいつまで人々の目を覆うのか

translation.en: How long? Not long.
translation.ja: いつまで？　長くない

translation.en: Because the arc of the moral universe is long,
translation.ja: 空を描く天空の弧は長いが

translation.en: but it bends toward justice.
-How long? Not long! -[man] Not long.
translation.ja: いつまで？ 長くない

translation.en: [in Spanish] Everyone has a right to life, liberty,
translation.ja: 〈誰にも自由になる権利がある〉

translation.en: -religion... -To vote.
[Dagoberto] There wasn’t justice at that time.
To have someone else oppress you
translation.ja: 〈誰かが無理やり抑圧するのは良くない〉

translation.en: -is not right. -[Alexandra] Forcefully, right?
translation.ja: 〈誰かが無理やり抑圧するのは良くない〉 〈ええ〉

translation.en: [in Chinese] As humans, we are never perfect. We have our shortcomings.
America has its shortcomings.
However...
America’s political system, belief system...
translation.ja: 〈米国の政治体制や信念体系が〉

translation.en: are trying to overcome these shortcomings.
Its political system is moving towards the right direction.
translation.ja: 〈正しい方向に向かおうとしている〉

translation.en: [in Spanish] For things to move forward and get better,
translation.ja: 〈改善する過程で誰かが苦しむ〉

translation.en: someone has to suffer.
At that time, they’re the ones who suffered.
[Rijkers, in English] You understand why he became such an important leader
translation.ja: この見事な演説で なぜ彼がリーダーになり得たかが分かる

translation.en: of that movement, because he was a great speaker.
translation.ja: なぜ彼がリーダーになり得たかが分かる

translation.en: This was such a long fight, and there were so many things we couldn't discuss today,
translation.ja: 長い話なので今日は時間がないけど

translation.en: there were so many ways in which African Americans were fighting for equality and still are today.
translation.ja: アフリカ系米国人は反人種差別運動を行った

translation.en: The final thing we have to do is just cover some of the questions.
translation.ja: 最後にテストに出る質問を

translation.en: What movement tried to end racial discrimination?
translation.ja: 人種差別に対する運動は？

translation.en: -[group] Civil Rights. -[Rijkers] Civil Rights Movement.
translation.ja: 公民権 公民権運動ね

translation.en: So "civil" means "of the people."
[woman] Jian Zhang.
[Zhang, in Chinese] I came to the US in 1999
to do my doctoral study in physics.
And now, I’ve been accepted as a member of the society.
I feel that all my years
of admiring America's value system have finally been valued.
All my years of yearning its value system have been valued.
translation.ja: 〈この国への憧憬が報われたと感じる〉

translation.en: I am now part of the American society.
[man, in English] Behind me, you see the eagle,
translation.ja: 後ろに鷲(わし)が見えますね

translation.en: the symbol of the United States of America.
translation.ja: アメリカ合衆国の象徴です

translation.en: We are a beautiful and substantive and powerful nation
translation.ja: この国は美しく… この国は美しく…クンツ地区裁判所判事 クンツ地区裁判所判事 クンツ地区裁判所判事独立した強大な国家です 独立した強大な国家です

translation.en: because of what you have contributed and because of what you will contribute.
translation.ja: 皆様の過去から未来に渡る貢献が支えます

translation.en: Just what is this sacred liberty
translation.ja: 人々の心にあるべき 人々の心にあるべきギンズバーグ最高裁判事

translation.en: that must lie in the hearts of men and women?
translation.ja: ギンズバーグ最高裁判事 ギンズバーグ最高裁判事神聖な自由とは何か？ ギンズバーグ最高裁判事

translation.en: The spirit of liberty is the spirit
which is not too sure it is right.
The spirit of liberty
is the spirit which seeks to understand
the minds of other men and women without bias.
translation.ja: 他人を理解しようとする精神です

translation.en: May the spirit of liberty be your beacon
translation.ja: 自由の精神を指針とし

translation.en: as you play your part in helping to achieve
translation.ja: より完全な国家同一体に到達できるよう―

translation.en: a more perfect union.
[in Spanish] This country has a history of struggle
for all of the rights that are enjoyed now.
When you’re a citizen, you can vote, you can run for office.
translation.ja: 〈市民であれば投票や立候補ができる〉

translation.en: This is a country of immigrants.
Who is not an immigrant in this country?
[in English] Albania, Algeria, Argentina,
translation.ja: アルバニアアルジェリア…

translation.en: Australia, Burkina Faso, Canada, China, Denmark,
translation.ja: オーストラリアカナダ　中国…

translation.en: Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Georgia.
translation.ja: エクアドルエルサルバドル…

translation.en: We're all from somewhere else.
translation.ja: 出身国はさまざまです

translation.en: We are a nation made strong by people like you.
translation.ja: このような人々がこの国を支えています

translation.en: People who have traveled long distances
overcome great obstacles,
all to provide a better life for themselves and their families.
translation.ja: より良き生活を自身や家族に与えるために

translation.en: Please, raise your right hand and repeat after me.
translation.ja: 右手を掲げ復唱してください

translation.en: -"I hereby declare..." -[crowd] I hereby declare.
-"...on oath..." -[crowd] On oath.
-"...that I absolutely..." -[crowd] That I absolutely.
-"...and entirely..." -[crowd] And entirely.
-"...renounce and abjure..." -[crowd] Renounce and abjure.
-"...all allegiance and fidelity..." -[crowd] All allegiance and fidelity.
[Ginsburg] "To any foreign prince..."
-"...State, or sovereignty..." -[crowd] State, or sovereignty.
"And that I take this obligation freely..."
-"So help me God." -[Judge Kuntz] "So help me God."
[woman] Yay, we did it!
